author: juliantg
content: https://etherscan.io/chart/blocktime here you can see the historical blocktimes, I wouldn't call this spiking at the moment

author: Deleted User
content: Just because we had it terrible before doesnt mean we arent spiking now though. At least traffic is low now at 14gwei

author: mrabino1
content: ironic as it may be, i also think we may see a significant increase in hash power as we approach the merge thus potentially reducing the block time even with the increased difficulty...

author: mrabino1
content: either way, unless a material risk is discovered or the underlying sw just isn't ready, i would recommend pushing forward. the difficulty bomb was introduced specifically for this very reason to motivate collaboration and updates (in whatever form)... from my lens, presently reduced gas prices and the importance of the merge mixed with what by most accounts that the sw is "there", gets me over the line to say "carry on"....

author: mrabino1
content: if we see something material come up, we can always tap the brakes if needed.

author: chris2_2_2
content: Hashpower doesn’t affect it much since it’ll just balance itself

author: jgm
content:
Not convinced by those numbers from Etherscan.  Taking yesterday as an example:
  - first block of the day was 14820221 (assuming UTC)
  - last block of the day was 14814062
  - this is 6160 blocks
  - with 86,400 seconds in a day that gives 14.03 seconds per block, rather than Etherscan's reported 13.85

Attached is an alternative graph for block times.  The earlier growth drops off was when arrow glacier was deployed, for comparison purposes.
